title: Travel Safely in Arctic Conditions
brief: Navigate arctic hazards including thin ice, whiteout conditions, and avalanche zones.
steps: Step 1: Never travel during blizzards or whiteout conditions - impossible to judge terrain.
Step 2: Cross thin ice by lying flat and crawling to distribute weight.
Step 3: Cross snow bridges at right angles, probe ahead with pole or ice axe for strength.
Step 4: Cross streams when water level is lowest - levels can vary 2-2.5 meters daily.
Step 5: Use snowshoes when snow is 30+ centimeters deep.
Step 6: Travel in early morning in avalanche-prone areas.
Step 7: Make camp early to allow time for proper shelter construction.
Step 8: Be aware that clear arctic air makes distance estimation difficult - you usually underestimate.
warnings: Avoid snow-covered streams - snow insulates and may prevent ice formation over water.
Avoid cornices (overhanging snow piles on lee side of ridges) - they can break if stepped on.
Traveling on foot in deep snow without snowshoes/skis leaves obvious trail for pursuers.
Some frozen rivers may have soft, open areas making travel difficult or impossible.
